  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath2 be a vector configuration in @xmath3 and @xmath4 the corresponding affine semigroup .",
    "we grade the polynomial ring @xmath5 $ ] over any field @xmath6 by the semigroup @xmath7 setting @xmath8 for @xmath9 . for @xmath10",
    ", we define the @xmath11-_degree _ of the monomial @xmath12 to be @xmath13 the _ toric ideal _",
    "@xmath14 associated to @xmath11 is the prime ideal generated by all the binomials @xmath15 such that @xmath16 , see @xcite . for such binomials ,",
    "we define @xmath17 .",
    "toric ideals have a large number of applications in several areas including : algebraic statistics , biology , computer algebra , computer aided geometric design , dynamical systems , hypergeometric differential equations , integer programming , mirror symmetry , toric geometry and graph theory , see @xcite . in graph theory",
    "there are several monomial or binomial ideals associated to a graph , see @xcite , depending on the properties one wishes to study .",
    "one of them is the toric ideal of a graph which has been extensively studied over the last years , see @xcite .",
    "the toric ideals are _ binomial ideals _ ,",
    "i.e. polynomial ideals generated by binomials .",
    "there are certain binomials in a toric ideal , such as minimal , indispensable , primitive , circuit and fundamental binomials provide crucial information about the ideal and therefore they have been studied in more detail . +",
    "a binomial @xmath18 is called _ minimal _ if it belongs to at least one minimal system of generators of @xmath19 .",
    "the minimal binomials , up to scalar multiple , are finitely many .",
    "their number is computed in @xcite in terms of combinatorial invariants of a simplicial complex associated to the toric ideal .",
    "the minimal binomials are characterized as the binomials that can not be written as a combination of binomials of smaller @xmath11-degree , see @xcite . + a binomial @xmath18",
    "is called _ indispensable _ if there exists a nonzero constant multiple of it to every minimal system of generators of @xmath19 . a recent problem arising from algebraic statistics",
    "is when a toric ideal have a unique minimal system of binomial generators , see @xcite . to study this problem ohsugi and hibi introduced in @xcite the notion of indispensable binomials and they gave necessary and sufficient conditions for toric ideals associated with certain finite graphs to possess unique minimal systems of binomial generators .",
    "+ an irreducible binomial @xmath20 in @xmath14 is called _ primitive _ if there exists no other binomial @xmath21 such that @xmath22 divides @xmath23 and @xmath24 divides @xmath25 .",
    "the set of all primitive binomials forms the graver basis of the toric ideal , see @xcite .",
    "it follows from the definition that a non primitive binomial can be written as a sum of products of monomials times binomials of @xmath19 of smaller @xmath11-degree therefore minimal binomials must be primitive , see also lemma 3.1 of @xcite .",
    "+ the support of a monomial @xmath26 of @xmath27 $ ] is @xmath28 and the support of a binomial @xmath29 is @xmath30 .",
    "an irreducible binomial @xmath31 belonging to @xmath14 is called a _ circuit _ of @xmath14 if there is no binomial @xmath32 such that @xmath33 .",
    "a binomial @xmath34 is a circuit of @xmath14 if and only if @xmath35 $ ] is generated by @xmath31 .",
    "+ for a vector @xmath36 we define @xmath37 . for a semigroup @xmath7",
    "we denote @xmath38 $ ] the semigroup ring of @xmath7 .",
    "the semigroup ring @xmath38 $ ] is isomorphic to the quotient @xmath5/i_a$ ] , see @xcite .",
    "let @xmath39 be a subset of @xmath40 then @xmath41 is the set @xmath42 .",
    "the semigroup ring @xmath43 $ ] is called combinatorial pure subring of @xmath38 $ ] , see @xcite and for a generalization , see @xcite .",
    "a binomial @xmath18 is called _ fundamental _ if there exists a combinatorial pure subring @xmath43 $ ] such that @xmath44\\cap i_a = i_{a_{{f}}}=<b>$ ] .",
    "these kinds of binomials are related to each other .",
    "the indispensable binomials are always minimal and the minimal are always primitive . also the fundamental binomials are circuits and indispensable , while the circuits are also primitive .",
    "the toric ideals of graphs is the best kind of toric ideals in order to understand how circuits , fundamentals , primitive , minimal and indispensable binomials are related , see theorems [ circuit ] , [ primitive ] , [ fundam ] , [ minimal ] , [ indispen ] , and to show that the above relations are strict , see example [ example ] .",
    "actually the toric ideal of a graph gives a way to ` view ' the ideal through the graph , but also to construct toric ideals with desired properties . in the case of the toric ideal of a graph",
    "there were several articles in the literature that characterize these kinds of binomials , most of them for particular cases of graphs , see @xcite .",
    "the aim of this article is to characterize primitive , minimal , indispensable and fundamental binomials of a toric ideal of a graph for a general graph and thus understanding better the toric ideal .",
    "these characterizations maybe useful to solve problems in the theory of toric ideals of graphs .",
    "the results in this paper are inspired and guided by the work of oshugi and hibi @xcite . in section 2 we present some terminology , notations and results about the toric ideals of graphs . in section 3",
    "we provide the converse of the characterization of ohsugi and hibi @xcite of the primitive elements of toric ideals of graphs . in section 4",
    "we characterize the minimal , the indispensable and the fundamental binomials of the toric ideal of a graph and we give an example that explains the relations between fundamental , primitive , circuit , minimal and indispensable binomials . at the end",
    "we remark that although the results in the article are stated and proved for simple graphs , they are also valid with small adjustments for general graphs with loops and multiple edges , see remark [ remark ] .",
    "in the next chapters , @xmath1 will be a finite simple connected graph on the vertex set @xmath45 , except at the final remark [ remark ] where the graph @xmath1 may have multiple edges and loops .",
    "let @xmath46 be the set of edges of @xmath1 and @xmath47 $ ] the polynomial ring in the @xmath48 variables @xmath49 over a field @xmath50 .",
    "we will associate each edge @xmath51 with @xmath52 in the free abelian group generated by the vertices and let @xmath53 .",
    "with @xmath54 we denote the toric ideal @xmath55 in @xmath47 $ ] .    a _ walk",

    ". _ length _ of the walk @xmath61 is called the number @xmath66 of edges of the walk .",
    "an even ( respectively odd ) walk is a walk of _ even _",
    "( respectively odd ) length .",
    "a walk @xmath67 is called _ closed _ if @xmath68 . a _ cycle _ is a closed walk @xmath69 with @xmath70 for every @xmath71 .",
    "depending on the property of the walk that we want to emphasize we may denote a walk @xmath61 by a sequence of vertices and edges @xmath72 or only vertices @xmath73 or only edges @xmath74 or the edges and vertices that we want to emphasize and sometimes we separate the walk into subwalks . for a walk @xmath75",
    "we denote by @xmath76 the walk @xmath77 .",
    "note that , although the graph @xmath1 has no multiple edges , the same edge @xmath78 may appear more than once in a walk . in this case @xmath78 is called _ multiple edge of the walk @xmath61_. if @xmath79 is a subwalk of @xmath61 then it follows from the definition of a subwalk that the multiplicity of an edge in @xmath79 is less than or equal to the multiplicity of the same edge in @xmath61 .",
    "given an even closed walk @xmath80 of the graph @xmath1 we denote by @xmath81 and by @xmath82 the binomial @xmath83 belonging to the toric ideal @xmath0 .",
    "actually the toric ideal @xmath0 is generated by binomials of this form , see @xcite .",
    "the same walk can be written in different ways but the corresponding binomials may differ only in the sign .",
    "note also that different walks may correspond to the same binomial .",
    "for example both walks @xmath84 and @xmath85 of the graph @xmath86 in figure 1 correspond to the same binomial @xmath87 . for convenience by @xmath88",
    "we denote the subgraph of @xmath1 with vertices the vertices of the walk and edges the edges of the walk @xmath61 .",
    "if @xmath89 is a subset of the vertex set @xmath90 of @xmath1 then the _ induced subgraph _ of @xmath1 on @xmath89 is the subgraph of @xmath1 whose vertex set is @xmath89 and whose edge set is @xmath91 . when @xmath61 is a closed walk we denote by @xmath92 the induced graph of @xmath1 on the set of vertices @xmath93 of @xmath94 .",
    "an even closed walk @xmath95 is said to be primitive if there exists no even closed subwalk @xmath96 of @xmath61 of smaller length such that @xmath97 and @xmath98 .",
    "the walk @xmath61 is primitive if and only if the binomial @xmath82 is primitive .",

    "a necessary characterization of the primitive elements were given by ohsugi and hibi in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 2.1 ) :    [ prim ] let @xmath1 be a finite connected graph . if @xmath109 is primitive , then we have @xmath110 where @xmath61 is one of the following even closed walks :    1 .",
    "@xmath61 is an even cycle of @xmath1 2 .",
    "@xmath111 , where @xmath112 and @xmath113 are odd cycles of @xmath1 having exactly one common vertex 3 .",
    "@xmath114 , where @xmath112 and @xmath113 are odd cycles of @xmath1 having no common vertex and where @xmath115 and @xmath116 are walks of @xmath1 both of which combine a vertex @xmath117 of @xmath112 and a vertex @xmath118 of @xmath113 .",
    "it is easy to see that any binomial in the first two cases is always primitive but this is not true in the third case .",
    "theorem [ primitive ] characterizes completely all primitive binomials .",
    "we will finish this section with a necessary and sufficient characterization of circuits that was given by villarreal in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 4.2 ) :    [ circuit]let @xmath1 be a finite connected graph .",
    "the binomial @xmath109 is circuit if and only if @xmath110 where    1 .",
    "@xmath61 is an even cycle or 2 .   two odd cycles intersecting in exactly one vertex or 3 .   two vertex disjoint odd cycles joined by a path .",
    "the aim of this chapter is to determine the form of primitive walks by making more precise the corresponding result by ohsugi - hibi , see theorem [ prim ] or ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 2.1 ) . + a _ cut edge _",
    "( respectively _ cut vertex _ ) is an edge ( respectively vertex ) of the graph whose removal increases the number of connected components of the remaining subgraph . a graph is called _ biconnected _ if it is connected and does not contain a cut vertex .",
    "a _ block _ is a maximal biconnected subgraph of a given graph @xmath1 .",
    "+ every even primitive walk @xmath119 partitions the set of edges in the two sets @xmath120 , otherwise the binomial @xmath82 is not irreducible .",
    "+ the edges of @xmath121 are called odd edges of the walk and those of @xmath122 even . note that for a closed even walk whether an edge is even or odd depends only on the edge that you start counting from .",
    "so it is not important to identify whether an edge is even or odd but to separate the edges in the two disjoint classes . _",
    "sink _ of a block @xmath31 is a common vertex of two odd or two even edges of the walk @xmath61 which belong to the block @xmath31 . in particular",
    "if @xmath78 is a cut edge of a primitive walk then @xmath78 appears at least twice in the walk and belongs either to @xmath121 or @xmath122",
    ". therefore both vertices of @xmath78 are sinks .",
    "sink is a property of the walk @xmath61 and not of the underlying graph @xmath88 .",
    "for example in figure 1a the walk @xmath123 has no sink , while in the walk @xmath124 all four vertices are sinks .",
    "note also that the walk @xmath125 in figure 1a has one cut vertex which is not a sink of either block .",
    "the walk @xmath126 in figure 1b has two cut vertices which are both sinks of all of their blocks .",
    "theorem [ primitive ] explains that this is because the first one is not primitive while the second is .",
    "+ figure 2 .",
    "[ primitive ] let @xmath1 a graph and @xmath61 an even closed walk of @xmath1 .",
    "the walk @xmath61 is primitive if and only if    1 .",
    "every block of @xmath88 is a cycle or a cut edge , 2 .",
    "every multiple edge of the walk @xmath61 is a double edge of the walk and a cut edge of @xmath88 , 3 .",
    "every cut vertex of @xmath88 belongs to exactly two blocks and it is a sink of both .    * proof .",
    "* let @xmath61 be an even primitive closed walk and let b be a block of @xmath94 which is not a cut edge .",
    "we will prove that it is a cycle .",
    "suppose not .",
    "let @xmath127 and @xmath128 the closed subwalk of @xmath61 such that the graph of @xmath129 is the block @xmath31 , where @xmath130 are all the edges of the walk @xmath61 that belong to the the block @xmath31 and @xmath131 .",
    "this is a closed walk since two blocks intersect in at most one point which is a cut vertex of the graph @xmath94 .",
    "since @xmath31 is not a cycle , there must be at least one vertex of the walk @xmath132 which appears twice in @xmath132 .",
    "if it was exactly one vertex like that then it should be a cut vertex of @xmath31 contradicting the biconnectivity of the block @xmath31 .",
    "therefore , there must exist at least two vertices @xmath133 of the block @xmath31 that appear at least twice in the walk @xmath132 and so @xmath61 can be written @xmath134 , where @xmath135 are subwalks of @xmath61 .",
    "note that the vertices @xmath133 are in this order in @xmath61 since otherwise @xmath136 or @xmath137 will be a cut vertex of @xmath31 .",
    "the walk @xmath61 is primitive , therefore the closed walk @xmath138 is odd , one of the lengths of the subwalks @xmath139 has the same parity as the length of @xmath140 , and both the first edge of @xmath115 and the last of @xmath116 belong to @xmath121 . combining all these , exactly one of the two closed walks @xmath141 or @xmath142 is a closed even subwalk of @xmath61 such that either @xmath143 and @xmath144 or @xmath145 and @xmath146 .",
    "this contradicts the primitiveness of @xmath61 .",
    "so every block is a cycle or a cut edge .",
    "+ let @xmath147 be a multiple edge of @xmath61 . whenever @xmath78 appears is either in @xmath121 or @xmath122 , since @xmath61 is a primitive walk .",
    "the edge @xmath78 may appear in the walk @xmath61 in two different ways , as @xmath148 or @xmath149 .",
    "there are two cases .",
    "first case : at least two times the edge appears in the same way @xmath150 ( or @xmath149 ) .",
    "then the walk @xmath61 can be written in the form @xmath151 . since @xmath61 is primitive and @xmath78",
    "is written as the first edge of @xmath61 , all the times that @xmath78 appears is in @xmath121 .",
    "therefore the walk @xmath152 is odd , which means that @xmath153 is an even closed walk , @xmath154 and @xmath155 .",
    "this contradicts the primitiveness of the walk @xmath61 .",
    "+ second case : the edge @xmath78 appears exactly twice in the walk and in the two different ways , so @xmath156 .",
    "as before the walks @xmath152 , @xmath157 are odd , therefore the first and the last edges of @xmath152 and @xmath157 all belong to @xmath122 .",
    "suppose that @xmath78 is not a cut edge of @xmath88 then the @xmath152 , @xmath157 have at least one common vertex @xmath158 .",
    "we rewrite @xmath61 as @xmath159 .",
    "since @xmath157 is an odd walk , one of @xmath160 is odd and the other is even .",
    "therefore exactly one of the two walks @xmath161 , @xmath162 is an even closed walk @xmath96 such that @xmath154 and @xmath155 , contradicting the primitiveness of the walk @xmath61 .",
    "we conclude that @xmath78 is a double edge of the walk @xmath61 and a cut edge of @xmath88 .",
    "+ let @xmath136 be a cut vertex , then it belongs to at least two blocks .",
    "since @xmath136 is a cut vertex @xmath61 can be written as @xmath163 . where @xmath164 are in the same block @xmath31 and @xmath165",
    ". then @xmath166 are both in @xmath121 .",
    "otherwise @xmath167 is an even closed subwalk of @xmath61 , contradicting the primitiveness of the walk @xmath61 .",
    "so @xmath136 is a sink and the subwalk @xmath168 is odd .",
    "similarly the walk @xmath169 is odd and @xmath170 are both in @xmath122 . then @xmath171 is an even subwalk of @xmath61 such that @xmath172 and @xmath173 and since @xmath61 is primitive @xmath174 . we conclude that @xmath136 belongs to exactly two blocks of @xmath94 and it is a sink of both",
    ". conversely let @xmath61 be an even closed walk satisfying the three conditions of the theorem which is not primitive .",
    "then there exists a primitive subwalk @xmath79 of @xmath61 of smaller length than @xmath61 , such that @xmath172 and @xmath173 . from the first part of the proof",
    "we know that also @xmath79 satisfies the three conditions of the theorem [ primitive ] .",
    "we claim that the graphs @xmath94 and @xmath175 have exactly the same blocks .",
    "let @xmath176 be a block of @xmath79 then there exists a block @xmath82 of @xmath61 such that @xmath177 . from the first condition",
    "@xmath176 is a cut edge or a cycle .",
    "suppose that @xmath178 is a cut edge of @xmath175 then @xmath78 must be double edge of @xmath79 . since @xmath172 and @xmath173 the edge @xmath78 is a multiple edge of @xmath61 and therefore from the second condition a cut edge of @xmath94 , thus a block of @xmath94 .",
    "in the case that @xmath176 is a cycle obviously @xmath82 is the same cycle and therefore @xmath179 .",
    "so all blocks of @xmath180 are blocks of @xmath181 .",
    "conversely suppose that there exist a block of @xmath181 which is not a block of @xmath180 .",
    "since @xmath94 is connected there must be at least one block of @xmath181 which is not a block of @xmath180 and has a contact point with @xmath180 .",
    "then this point should be a sink of both since @xmath182 and @xmath183 .",
    "but if it is a sink of @xmath79 then it should belong to exactly two blocks of @xmath175 .",
    "this implies that it should belong to at least three blocks of @xmath94 , a contradiction to the third property of @xmath61 .",
    "+ therefore the graphs @xmath94 and @xmath184 are identical and every simple edge of the walk @xmath79 is a simple edge of @xmath61 and every double edge ( cut edge ) of the walk @xmath79 is a double edge of @xmath61",
    ". therefore @xmath185 and @xmath186",
    ". therefore they have the same length , a contradiction .",
    "we conclude that @xmath61 is primitive .",
    "@xmath187    from theorem [ primitive ] easily follows the following corrolary that describes the underlying graph of a primitive walk .",
    "[ primitive - graph ] let @xmath1 a graph and @xmath89 a subgraph of @xmath1 .",
    "the subgraph @xmath89 is the graph @xmath94 of a primitive walk @xmath61 if and only if    1 .",
    "every block of @xmath89 is a cycle or a cut edge and 2 .",
    "every cut vertex of @xmath89 belongs to exactly two blocks and separates the graph in two parts , the total number of edges of the cyclic blocks in each part is odd .",
    "the first aim of this section is to characterize the walks @xmath61 of the graph @xmath1 such that the binomial @xmath82 belongs to a minimal system of generators of the ideal @xmath0 .",
    "certainly the walk has to be primitive , but this is not enouph .",
    "the walk must have more properties , the first one it depends on the graph @xmath94 and the rest on the induced graph @xmath92 of @xmath61 , see proposition [ sprim ] and theorem [ minimal ] .",
    "the binomial @xmath188 is minimal therefore the walk @xmath61 is primitive .",
    "suppose that @xmath61 is not strongly primitive , then there exist two sinks @xmath65 of the same block @xmath31 with distance one .",
    "we will call @xmath78 the edge @xmath189 .",
    "then @xmath61 can be written as @xmath190 for some walks @xmath191 , where at least the first and the last edge of @xmath192 are in the block @xmath31 .",
    "the walks @xmath193 are closed walks and since @xmath61 is primitive they are necessarily odd .",
    "therefore @xmath194 is also odd .",
    "so the first and the last edge of @xmath192 , as also @xmath78 are in @xmath122 .",
    "since @xmath133 are sinks the closed walks @xmath195 and @xmath196 are both even and the binomial @xmath197 is not minimal , a contradiction .",
    "note that @xmath198 , otherwise the even closed walk @xmath152 or @xmath157 has length 2 , which is impossible since @xmath1 has no multiple edges .",
    "@xmath187    while the property of a walk to be primitive depends only on the graph @xmath94 , the property of the walk to be minimal or indispensable depends also on the induced graph @xmath92 .",
    "an edge @xmath199 of the graph @xmath1 is called a _ chord _ of the walk @xmath61 if the vertices of the edge @xmath199 belong to @xmath200 and @xmath201 . in other words an edge",
    "is called chord of the walk @xmath61 if it belongs to @xmath202 but not in @xmath203 .",
    "let @xmath61 be an even closed walk @xmath204 and @xmath205 a chord of @xmath61 .",
    "then @xmath199 _ breaks _ @xmath61 in two walks : @xmath206 and @xmath207 where @xmath208 and @xmath209 the two walks are both even or both odd .",
    "a chord @xmath210 is called bridge of a primitive walk @xmath61 if there exist two different blocks @xmath211 of @xmath88 such that @xmath212 and @xmath213 .",
    "a chord is called even ( respectively odd ) if it is not a bridge and breaks the walk in two even walks ( respectively in two odd walks ) .    in the walk of figure 4 , there are three chords which are bridges of @xmath61 , those marked by @xmath86 and there is one chord which is even , it is marked by @xmath214 . in the walks of figure 5 ,",
    "all chords are odd .",
    "note that the two vertices of a bridge may also belong to the same block , for example that happens in one of the three bridges in figure 4 .",

    "therefore one of the @xmath248 has to be odd and the other even .",
    "similarly for @xmath249 .",
    "note also that the four walks @xmath250 , @xmath251 , @xmath252 and @xmath253 give the same binomial .",
    "therefore we can assume that @xmath254 are odd and @xmath255 are even .",
    "then the two closed walks @xmath256 and @xmath257 are even and @xmath258 is not minimal , a contradiction . note that @xmath259 , since @xmath1 has no multiple edges .",
    "+ suppose now that @xmath61 has two odd chords @xmath260 which cross strongly effectively in @xmath61 .",
    "then @xmath61 is in the form @xmath261 .",
    "we have that the walks @xmath262 , and @xmath263 are even , since the walks @xmath264 are odd .",
    "then @xmath265 is not minimal , a contradiction .",
    "note that since the odd chords @xmath234 do not form an @xmath229 , @xmath266 .",
    "@xmath187    two primitive walks @xmath267 differ by an @xmath226 , @xmath268 , if @xmath269 and @xmath270 , where both @xmath248 are odd walks .",
    "two even closed walks @xmath267 are @xmath226-equivalent if either @xmath271 or there exists a series of walks @xmath272 such that @xmath273 and @xmath274 differ by an @xmath226 , where @xmath275 .",
    "note that if @xmath61 and @xmath79 are @xmath226-equivalent then the induced graphs @xmath92 and @xmath276 are equal .",
    "we denote by @xmath277 the equivalence class of @xmath61 under the @xmath226-equivalent relation .",
    "we say that an odd chord @xmath199 of a primitive walk @xmath269 crosses an @xmath226 , @xmath281 , if one of the vertices of @xmath199 is in @xmath282 , the other in @xmath283 and @xmath199 is different from @xmath284",
    ".      * proof .",
    "* let @xmath82 be a minimal binomial .",
    "suppose that there exists an odd chord @xmath285 that crosses the @xmath226 , @xmath281 , of the walk @xmath269",
    ". then @xmath61 can be written in the form @xmath286 .",
    "the chord @xmath199 is odd therefore the walks @xmath287 and @xmath288 are both odd .",
    "also , since @xmath281 is an @xmath226 , the walks @xmath152 and @xmath157 are both odd .",
    "therefore @xmath289 and @xmath290 are both even .",
    "so , from the definition , @xmath199 is an even chord of @xmath291 .",
    "note that @xmath199 is not a bridge of @xmath79 since it is not a bridge of @xmath61 .",
    "therefore from proposition [ minimal1 ] @xmath176 is not minimal and from proposition [ minimal2 ] @xmath82 is not minimal , a contradiction .",
    "@xmath187    in fact , for a primitive walk @xmath61 the walks in @xmath277 are primitive , an @xmath226 of @xmath61 is an @xmath226 for all walks in @xmath277 , although sometimes chords and edges change role .",
    "a bridge of @xmath61 is a bridge for every walk in @xmath277 and odd chords of @xmath61 ( respectively even chords ) are odd chords ( respectively even chords ) for every walk in @xmath277 , except if they cross an @xmath226 . in the last case",
    "they may change parity , it depends on how many @xmath226 they cross .",
    "[ minimal ] let @xmath61 be an even closed walk .",
    "@xmath188 is a minimal binomial if and only if @xmath61 is strongly primitive , all the chords of @xmath61 are odd , there are not two of them which cross strongly effectively and no odd chord crosses an @xmath226 of the walk @xmath61 .",
    "* proof . *",
    "the one direction follows from propositions [ minimal1 ] and [ minimal3 ] . for the converse ,",
    "let @xmath61 be an even closed walk such that all the chords of @xmath61 are odd , there are not two of them which cross strongly effectively and no odd chord crosses an @xmath226 of the walk @xmath61 .",
    "suppose that @xmath188 is not minimal .",
    "then there exists a minimal walk @xmath292 such that @xmath293 and @xmath294 , thus edges of @xmath295 are edges of @xmath296 .",
    "we have @xmath297 .",
    "this means that the vertices of @xmath298 are in @xmath94 and so edges of @xmath298 are edges or chords of @xmath61 , which means actually they are odd chords by hypothesis .",
    "+ we claim that every such @xmath299 is an @xmath226 of @xmath61 .",
    "suppose not , then among all those walks @xmath299 which are not @xmath226 of @xmath61 and @xmath293 and @xmath300 , we choose one , @xmath301 , such that @xmath302 has the fewest possible chords of @xmath61 .",
    "+ first case : the walk @xmath302 does not have any chords of @xmath61 , then all edges of @xmath303 are edges of @xmath61 , so @xmath304 and @xmath305 and since @xmath61 is primitive then there exists at least one @xmath306",
    ". therefore @xmath307 , where all edges @xmath308 are in @xmath296 .",
    "note that whenever there are two blocks joined by a cut vertex , the adjoining edges in the two different blocks have different parity , since the walk @xmath61 is primitive .",
    "thus all the edges @xmath308 are in one block of @xmath61 , which necessarily is a cycle and then the two vertices in between are sinks of @xmath61 . a contradiction to strongly primitiveness .",
    "note that if two of @xmath308 are the same edge , then this edge will be a double edge of @xmath61 and therefore a cut edge of @xmath94 , so the edges @xmath308 are in two blocks , a contradiction . +",
    "second case : @xmath303 has at least one chord of @xmath61 . then @xmath309 where @xmath310 are subwalks of @xmath61 and @xmath311 are odd chords of @xmath61 satisfying the hypotheses and @xmath312 is minimal .",
    "both vertices of an odd chord @xmath199 of @xmath61 are in the same cyclic block , thus @xmath199 divides @xmath61 into two regions @xmath313 .",
    "there must exist at least one chord @xmath314 such that the region @xmath315 does not contain a chord . the last edge of @xmath273 and the first of @xmath274 are in @xmath316 .",
    "the chord @xmath317 is odd , therefore the one of these two edges is in @xmath318 and the other in @xmath319 . without loss of generality",
    "we can suppose that the first edge of @xmath274 is in @xmath318 .",
    "the walk @xmath301 is closed and none of the vertices of @xmath317 is a cut vertex of @xmath302 , since @xmath317 is not a bridge of @xmath61 , therefore there must be a chord which has a vertex in @xmath315 and a vertex in @xmath320 .",
    "this chord is the @xmath321 since @xmath318 does not contain a chord .",
    "let @xmath322 and @xmath323 .",
    "since the first and the last edge of @xmath274 are in @xmath324 , @xmath325 ( the number of edges of @xmath274 ) is odd .",
    "but from the hypothesis @xmath326 can not cross effectively except if they form an @xmath229 , which means that either @xmath327 or @xmath328 . in the first case",
    "@xmath61 is an @xmath226 , the @xmath329 . in the second case",
    "there exists an even minimal walk @xmath330 with two less chords , a contradiction to the minimality of the chords of @xmath301 .",
    "we conclude that if for a walk @xmath299 we have @xmath293 and @xmath300 , then @xmath292 is an @xmath226 of @xmath61 .",
    "remark that the conditions of theorem [ minimal ] if they are satisfied by the walk @xmath61 , then they are also satisfied by any other walk in @xmath277 .",
    "we fix a minimal set @xmath331 of binomial generators for the ideal @xmath332 , for some even closed walks @xmath333 . for a @xmath334",
    "we define @xmath335 and @xmath336 is the number of monomials of @xmath337 .",
    "we take a walk @xmath338 such that @xmath339 is minimal .",
    "we claim that @xmath340 is one of the minimal generators @xmath341 .",
    "suppose not , then it is written in the form @xmath342 and without loss of generality we can suppose that @xmath343 and @xmath344 is a monomial in @xmath345 .",
    "then @xmath346 is necessarily an @xmath226 , @xmath281 , of @xmath347 and @xmath348 .",
    "consider @xmath349 , then @xmath350 and @xmath351 but then @xmath352 which is a contradiction .",
    "note that the coefficients of the monomials in @xmath353 are @xmath354 or @xmath355 , see @xcite for more information about the generation of a toric ideal . + therefore @xmath340 is minimal and from proposition [ minimal2 ] @xmath82 is minimal .",
    "@xmath187    note that in the cases in theorem [ minimal ] where we have more than one @xmath226 , two @xmath226 of the walk can not have a common edge and they can not cross , since in all these cases we get an odd chord which crosses an @xmath226 .",
    "[ indispen ] let @xmath61 be an even closed walk .",
    "@xmath188 is an indispensable binomial if and only if @xmath61 is a strongly primitive walk , all the chords of @xmath61 are odd and there are not two of them which cross effectively .    *",
    "proof . * from proposition [ minimal2 ]",
    "if @xmath61 has an @xmath226 then @xmath82 is not indispensable , since it can be replaced by @xmath176 .",
    "so @xmath61 has not an @xmath226 , then the result follows from theorem [ minimal ] .",
    "conversely , let @xmath61 be a strongly primitive walk , all the chords of @xmath61 are odd and there are not two of them which cross effectively .",
    "suppose that @xmath188 is not indispensable .",
    "then there exists a minimal walk @xmath356 such that @xmath293 , thus edges of @xmath295 are edges of @xmath296 .",
    "we have @xmath357 .",
    "this means that the vertices of @xmath298 are in @xmath94 and so edges of @xmath298 are edges or chords of @xmath61 , which means actually they are odd chords by hypothesis .",
    "+ first case : the walk @xmath299 does not have any chords of @xmath61 . in that case",
    "the proof is exactly the same as in the corresponding part in the proof of theorem [ minimal ] .",
    "+ second case : @xmath298 has at least one chord of @xmath61 .",
    "then @xmath358 where @xmath310 are subwalks of @xmath61 and @xmath311 are odd chords of @xmath61 satisfying the hypotheses .",
    "there must exist at least one chord @xmath314 such that the region @xmath315 does not contain a chord . the last edge of @xmath273 and the first of @xmath274 are in @xmath359 .",
    "the chord @xmath317 is odd , therefore the one of these two edges is in @xmath318 and the other in @xmath319 . without loss of generality",
    "we can suppose that the first edge of @xmath274 is in @xmath318 .",
    "the walk @xmath292 is closed and none of the vertices of @xmath317 is a cut vertex of @xmath299 , since @xmath317 is not a bridge of @xmath61 , so there must be a chord of @xmath61 which has a vertex in @xmath315 and a vertex in @xmath320 .",
    "this chord is the @xmath321 since @xmath318 does not contain a chord .",
    "let @xmath322 and @xmath323 .",
    "since the first and the last edge of @xmath274 are in @xmath360 , the number of edges @xmath361 of @xmath274 is odd .",
    "therefore @xmath317 and @xmath321 cross effectively , a contradiction .",
    "+ therefore @xmath82 is indispensable .",
    "@xmath187    remark that combining theorem [ minimal ] , proposition [ minimal2 ] and theorem [ indispen ] , we have that if @xmath188 is indispensable then @xmath61 has no @xmath229 and if @xmath188 is minimal but not indispensable then @xmath188 has at least one @xmath229 .",
    "if no minimal generator has an @xmath226 then the toric ideal is generated by indispensable binomials , so the ideal @xmath0 has a unique system of binomial generators and conversely .",
    "an even closed walk @xmath61 of a graph @xmath1 is called _ fundamental _ if for every even closed walk @xmath79 of the induced subgraph of @xmath362 it holds @xmath363 .",
    "a binomial @xmath82 is fundamental if @xmath61 is fundamental , see @xcite .",
    "[ fundam ] if @xmath61 is an even closed walk , then the binomial @xmath82 is fundamental if and only if @xmath61 is a circuit and has no chords except in the case that it is a cycle with no even chords and at most one odd chord .",
    "* let @xmath61 be an even closed walk such that the binomial @xmath188 is fundamental . from (",
    "* theorem 1.1 . ) we know that @xmath188 is a circuit and @xmath188 is an indispensable binomial .",
    "since @xmath188 is a circuit , from proposition [ circuit ] there are three cases .",
    "if @xmath61 is a cycle the result follows from ( * ? ?",
    "* lemma 4.2 . ) . in the other two cases",
    ", @xmath61 is a circuit with no even chords and bridges , since @xmath188 is indispensable .",
    "suppose that @xmath61 has an odd chord .",
    "the odd chord necessarily is a chord of one of the two odd cycles .",
    "every chord of an odd cycle breaks the cycle in two cycles , one of which is odd and the other even .",
    "the even cycle gives a binomial in @xmath364 which is not in @xmath365 .",
    "a contradiction arises since @xmath188 is fundamental .",
    "conversely if @xmath61 is a cycle with no even chords and at most one odd chord , the result follows from ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 4.2 . ) . on the other hand",
    "if @xmath61 is not a cycle then it is a circuit with no chords .",
    "therefore @xmath61 has no even cycles and @xmath188 is fundamental .",
    "@xmath187      the simplest possible graph which shows that the relations between fundamental , primitive , indispensable , minimal binomials and circuits are strict is the following : let @xmath1 be the graph with 10 vertices and 14 edges of figure 6 .",
    "the graver basis has twenty two elements : @xmath366 , @xmath367 , @xmath368 , @xmath369 , @xmath370 , @xmath371 , @xmath372 , @xmath373 , @xmath374 , @xmath375 , @xmath376 , @xmath377 , @xmath378 , @xmath379 , @xmath380 , @xmath381 , @xmath382 , @xmath383 , @xmath384 , @xmath385 , @xmath386 , @xmath387 .",
    "the first eight of them are fundamental binomials .",
    "the first ten are indispensable binomials and the first sixteen binomials are minimal .",
    "note that the number of minimal generators @xmath388 is @xmath389 and there are @xmath390 different , up to non zero constants , minimal systems of binomial generators .",
    "the cause of the dispensability of the binomials @xmath391 is the existence of an @xmath226 , @xmath392 .",
    "the cause of the primitive elements @xmath393 and @xmath394 not to be minimal is the existence of bridges : @xmath395 in the first three and @xmath396 in the last three .",
    "finally all of them are circuits except the binomials @xmath397 .      for simplicity of the statements and the proofs we assumed that the graphs are simple .",
    "but actually most of the results are valid with small adjustments for graphs with loops and multiple edges .",
    "theorem [ primitive ] about primitive walks is true exactly as it is stated , but note that you may have cycles with one edge , a loop , and cycles with two edges , in the case that you have multiple edges between two vertices .",
    "the property of a walk to give a minimal binomial depends on the induced graph and one may have chords which are loops or multiple edges . in this case in theorem",
    "[ minimal ] , which describes the even closed walks that determine minimal generators , chords which are multiple edges are also permitted and loops where the vertex of the loop is not a cut vertex of @xmath94 . while in theorem [ indispen ] chords which are multiple edges are not permitted , but chords which are loops such that the vertices of the loops are not cut vertices of @xmath94 are permitted .",

    "<S> let @xmath0 be the toric ideal of a graph @xmath1 . </S>",
    "<S> we characterize in graph theoretical terms primitive , minimal , indispensable and fundamental binomials of the toric ideal @xmath0 </S>",
